journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Biomechanical Properties of Porcine Flexor Tendon Fixation With Varying Throws and Stitch Methods

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Saitama Medical University, Iruma-gun, Saitama, Japan
Investigation performed at the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Saitama Medical University, Iruma-gun, Saitama, Japan

author-notes.corresp: *Katsunobu Sakaguchi, MD, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Saitama Medical University, 38 Morohongo, Moroyama-machi, Iruma-gun, Saitama, 350-0495 Japan (e-mail: katsuguchi@msn.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The well-known suture technique configurations used for hamstring tendon autograft preparation in anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction are the Krackow locking stitch and nonlocking stitch, such as a baseball stitch and a whipstitch. However, there are few data in the literature regarding biomechanical comparisons of suture techniques.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to determine the properties of several current techniques of tendon graft suture employed in ACL reconstruction.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Controlled laboratory study.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Forty-two fresh-frozen porcine flexor digitorum tendons were used. Three stitch configurations (Krackow stitch [group K], baseball stitch [group B], and whipstitch [group W]) were assessed with varying suture throws (6 throws, group×6; 10 throws, group×10) using No. 5 Ethibond sutures. Each group was tested at 1500 loading cycles between 50 and 200 N. After loading cycles, the surviving tendons underwent a load-to-failure test.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: During the loading cycles, 3 of 7 specimens in group B×6 and all specimens in group W×6 failed by suture pullout. Four of 7 specimens in group B×10 and all specimens in group W×10 showed partial tearing of the tendon. Elongation of group B×10 and group W×10 showed significantly greater elongation than other groups (P < .05). Maximum loads at failure showed significant differences between group K and the other groups (K×6, 436 ± 52 N; K×10, 419 ± 34 N; P < .05). Most specimens failed by rupture of the suture thread in group K. Pullout of the suture from the tendon was observed most in groups B and W.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The Krackow stitch was superior to other stitch methods. There was, however, no significant effect of the number of throws on the holding strength.

sec.title: Clinical Relevance:
sec.p: The Krackow stitch could prevent suture slippage by a locking mechanism. The whipstitch is not suitable for clinical application even with an increased number of throws.

body.p: One of the most commonly used autologous anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) grafts has been the middle third of the patellar tendon, which is harvested with patellar and tibial bone blocks. However, the morbidity3,4,6 and functional deficit4,7,8,10 associated with harvest of the patellar tendon autograft have been recognized. On the other hand, hamstring tendon autograft harvesting is associated with minimal functional loss or donor site morbidity.15 Clinical studies have shown no statistically significant difference between the functional outcomes of patients treated with either bone–patellar tendon–bone or multiple-looped hamstring tendon grafts.2,16

A number of biomechanical studies of ACL reconstruction with hamstring tendon autografts have recently been reported.1,13,14,23,25 However, the authors employed a wide variety of suture techniques and suture throws with autograft preparation. The well-known suture technique configurations used for graft preparation are the Krackow locking stitch and nonlocking stitches, such as a baseball stitch1,5,21 and a whipstitch.9,22,25

In 1986, Krackow et al13 published the description of a new locking stitch with 3 locking No. 5 braided nonabsorbable sutures for fixating ligaments, tendons, or capsular components to bone. They reported a failure strength of 392 N, which is twice as strong as staple fixation into bone, when 2 Krackow sutures were placed into each end of the bovine medial collateral ligament.14 Jassem et al,12 in an in vitro study using rabbit Achilles tendon, demonstrated an increasing stiffness of 1-cm pitch using the Krackow stitch compared with 0.5-cm pitch, whereas failure loads and displacements were not different between the 2 groups. However, there are no data in the literature concerning biomechanical comparison of various suture techniques and suture throws when preparing hamstring tendon autografts.

During the early postoperative time, the ACL replacement graft will more likely experience cyclic submaximum than single maximum loading. Morrison19 calculated the mean peak force in the ACL during level walking to be 169 N. Zheng et al27 calculated the peak force in the ACL to be 142 N during seated knee extension. We analyzed biomechanical properties of the grafts employed in ACL reconstruction with loading cycles that were intended to simulate early rehabilitation exercises such as continuous passive motion and partial weightbearing. The purpose of this study was to determine the biomechanical properties of the several current suturing techniques with varying throws of the tendon graft.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Three stitch configurations were assessed with varying suture throws for this study. Forty-two fresh-frozen porcine flexor digitorum tendons were randomly assigned into 6 study groups. All tendons were stored at −20°C and thawed at room temperature for 24 hours before testing. Moisture of the tendons was maintained with saline sprays during preparation and testing.

All tendons were cut 12 cm in length and the cross-sectional area measured using an area micrometer (Meira Inc, Nagoya, Japan). There were 3 different configurations: Krackow stitch (group K), baseball stitch (group B), and whipstitch (group W). Tendons were sutured with No. 5 Ethibond sutures (Ethicon Inc, Somerville, New Jersey) using a total of 6 throws (group×6) or 10 throws (group×10) starting 5 mm from each of the tendon ends. The pitch between suture throws was 5 mm. Care was taken to tighten each individual stitch to remove excess suture material (Figure 1).

caption.p: The stitch configurations: (A) Krackow stitch, (B) baseball stitch, and (C) whipstitch.

sec.p: Biomechanical tests were performed on the tendons using an Instron 8872 materials testing machine (Instron Corp, Canton, Massachusetts). The tendon was folded to form a graft with 2 strands, and the looped end of the tendon was placed through a steel ring mounted in the machine. The suture ends of the tendon were tied around a bolt with 5 square knots and held on a nut (Figure 2). The loads were applied parallel to the axis of the specimen to simulate a worst-case scenario. A preload of 50 N was first applied to the tendon for 10 minutes. Thereafter, the tendons were loaded for 1500 loading cycles between 50 N and 200 N at 0.5 Hz. After loading cycles, the surviving tendons underwent a load-to-failure test at a cross-head speed of 20 mm/min. The response of the specimen to loading was automatically obtained in the form of a force-displacement curve. Elongation was defined as the difference from the looped end of the tendon on a steel ring to the connecting bolt between the initial cyclic peak and the 1500 cyclic peak. Maximum failure load of each tendon was determined from the peak value in the load-displacement curve. Stiffness of each tendon was defined as the slope of the linear portion of the force-displacement curve during the load-to-failure test. The failure mechanism for each specimen was also recorded.

caption.p: Test specimen setup in a materials testing machine.

sec.p: Biomechanical testing data were analyzed by 1-way ANOVA with Dunnett multiple comparison tests. Statistical significance was set at P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Results of biomechanical data are summarized in Table 1. There were no significant differences of the average cross-sectional area among all groups. The mean elongation after preload of groups B×6 and W×6 was significantly higher than groups K×10, B×10, and W×10.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Three specimens in group B×6 and all specimens in group W×6 failed by suture pullout during cyclic loading.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Four specimens in group B×10 and all specimens in group W×10 showed partial tearing of the tendon during cyclic loading.

fn.label: c-f
fn.p: Significant difference among the groups: P < .05.

sec.p: During cyclic loading, 3 of 7 specimens in group B×6 and all specimens in group W×6 failed by suture pullout. Four of 7 specimens in group B×10 and all specimens in group W×10 showed partial tearing of the tendon. On the other hand, group K and group B×6 did not show partial tearing of the tendon. The mean elongation after 1500 loading cycles of groups B×10 (12.2 ± 2.9 mm) and W×10 (18.3 ± 1.5 mm) was significantly greater than the other groups (K×6, 5.8 ± 1.4 mm; K×10, 5.7 ± 1.5 mm; B×6, 5.8 ± 3.0 mm), and group W×10 was significantly greater than group B×10. Additionally, 80% of elongation occurred by 100 cycles during the cyclic load in all groups (Figure 3).

caption.p: A typical elongation-cycle curve demonstrated by group K×6 and group B×6 specimens.

sec.p: The mean maximum failure loads of group K (K×6, 436 ± 52 N; K×10, 419 ± 34 N) were significantly higher than those of other groups (B×6, 362 ± 24 N; B×10, 374 ± 82 N; W×10, 365 ± 24 N). There was no significant difference between group K×6 and group K×10, and the mean stiffness was not significantly different among all groups.

Modes of failure after a single-cycle load-to-failure test are presented in Table 2. Failure mode of all specimens showed either one of the 2 limbs. Most specimens failed by rupture of the suture thread in group K, while pullout of the suture from the tendon was observed most in group B and group W (Figure 4).

caption.p: Mode of Failure at Single-Cycle Load-to-Failure Test
Pullout of suture after load-to-failure test.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Recently, anatomic ACL reconstruction using multiple-looped hamstring tendons has been developed, and good clinical outcomes were reported.20,26 In ACL reconstruction with multiple-looped hamstring tendons, the grafts are sutured with several suture techniques and then fixed with various devices while the grafts are kept tensioned at their initial strength. Strength behavior of graft suturing configurations should significantly influence the biomechanical properties, especially in extracortical indirect fixation methods through suture linkage as a screw post fixation14,20 and the double spike plate.24 Therefore, choices of suture materials and stitch methods in graft preparation are an important concern.

Several authors have reported biomechanical properties of graft fixation techniques using various stitch methods. Steiner et al25 performed a biomechanical analysis by applying anterior tibial translation to cadaveric knees with hamstring tendon ACL reconstruction. The 4-stranded hamstring grafts were sutured with No. 5 Ethibond sutures (Ethicon Inc) placed in a whipstitch fashion. The suture strands at each end of the graft were tied around a screw post on the femur and tibia. With the washer technique, the free ends of the grafts were secured to the femur by 2 screws and soft screw washers. The looped ends were secured to the tibia by sutures placed through the looped ends and tied to a post. They reported that grafts fixed with washers and screws were superior to the screw post fixation. Most grafts with a screw post fixation failed by suture-tendon stretching. The washer technique failed by tendon stretch, tibial post pullout, and suture rupture.

Adam et al1 evaluated biomechanical properties of a hamstring graft fixed either with an interference screw or linkage suture material knotted over a button. Four-stranded porcine flexor hallucis tendons sewn with No. 2 Ethibond sutures (Ethicon Inc) using a running baseball fashion were fixed with a biodegradable interference screw or tied over a titanium button. Interference screw fixation of the graft was superior to suture button fixation with linkage material because it offered greater maximum pullout force and stiffness as well as less graft motion inside the bone tunnel. The grafts fixed with the interference screw failed because of graft slippage past the screw, whereas suture button fixation failed by a rupture of the linkage suture material.

Krackow et al14 compared the fixation strength of an original locking loop stitch (Krackow stitch) with standard staple fixation using bovine knee collateral ligament. They reported that with the Krackow stitch, suture rupture occurred when greater than 450 N of load was applied and staple fixation failed by slippage of the ligament at 200 N under cyclic loading test. On the other hand, Scheffler et al23 showed that titanium interference screw fixation decreased anterior displacement compared with extracortical fixation during the cyclic loading. For indirect extracortical fixation, Mersilene tape was placed through the folded human hamstring tendon loops and fixed by EndoButton (Smith & Nephew, Memphis, Tennessee) on the femoral cortex. The free tendon ends using No. 5 Ethibond sutures (Ethicon Inc) with a Krackow stitch were tied around a screw post on the tibial cortex. Most specimens failed by rupture of the sutures on the tibial side.

Although direct comparison is not possible because of a variety of biomechanical testing protocols, the nonlocking stitch configuration fails because of failure of the linkage between the graft and the suture material. In contrast, in the Krackow stitch, suture rupture is the mode of failure.

In the present study, all specimens using a whipstitch method with 6 throws failed by suture pullout during the cyclic loading test. Although increasing the number of the throws could prevent suture pullout, the elongation of group W×10 was significantly greater than that of the other groups because of partial tear of the specimens. With regard to failure mode, all of group W×10 were suture pullouts after the single-cycle load-to-failure test. Steiner et al25 reported 5 of 6 specimens placed in a whipstitch method failed by suture-tendon stretching of the entire graft. Therefore, a whipstitch method is not suitable for clinical application because sutures are easily pulled out from the tendon, even if the number of throws is increased.

Four specimens in group B×6 and all in group B×10 survived. In a baseball stitch, increasing the number of suture throws affected the mechanism of failure and decreased the pullout of sutures during cyclic loading. However, group B×10 showed significantly greater elongation than group B×6 because of partial rupture of the tendon. Most specimens failed by suture pullout from the tendon regardless of the number of throws. Three of 4 specimens (75.0%) in group B×6 and 6 of 7 specimens (85.9%) in group B×10 experienced suture pullout.

In a biomechanical study using porcine Achilles tendons, McKeon et al17 tested the Krackow stitch with 2, 4, or 6 paired locking loops. They showed no significant difference in peak load to failure and elongation regardless of the number of locking loops. In the current study, the Krackow stitch demonstrated the most superior biomechanical properties because of less suture pullout and elongation as well as greater maximum failure load than the whipstitch and baseball stitch groups. Furthermore, no significant difference was observed for elongation, maximum failure load, or stiffness between group K×6 and group K×10. There were no failures during cyclic loading even if the number of throws was fewer. Most specimens failed by rupture of the suture thread in the Krackow stitch group. The number of throws did not influence mode of failure. The Krackow stitch was able to prevent suture slippage by the locking mechanism, and there was no significant effect of the number of throws on the holding strength. Additional suture throws may increase the risk of eventually lengthening through slippage12,17; fewer throws may provide less potential for elongation caused by suture slippage.

The results of this study suggest that the Krackow stitch is usually preferable for suturing tendons than a whipstitch and a baseball stitch. However, residual anterior laxity of more than 3-mm difference from the uninvolved knee after ACL reconstruction has previously been classified as clinical failure.11 Elongation of the Krackow stitch was 5.8 mm for group K×6 and 5.7 mm for group K×10 after cyclic loading, and 80% of elongation occurred by 100 cycles during the cyclic load. Therefore, a surgeon must keep his or her mind on the possibility that the graft constructs using only the Krackow stitch and tied to a screw post may become loose during the early rehabilitation phase.

The present study has some limitations. First, we used the porcine flexor digitorum tendons instead of human hamstring tendons. Furthermore, the best portion of porcine tendons was used. The mechanical properties of the porcine tendon are not precisely the same but similar to those of human specimens.1,18,21 Second, the cyclic loading and load-to-failure test were performed with nonphysiological loads. Our study was not tested as the biomechanical properties of a human ACL reconstruction model but as only the tendon graft. Finally, this was an in vitro study, and it did not take into account the physiological healing process.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The Krackow stitch could prevent suture slippage by a locking mechanism. However, elongation of the Krackow stitch was above 5.7 mm for each group K after cyclic loading, and 80% of elongation occurred by 100 cycles during the cyclic load. On other hand, the whipstitch is not suitable for clinical application even with an increased number of throws.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
